Abstract: Insect eggs exhibit remarkable adaptive plasticity in response to diverse environmental challenges. This review synthesizes recent findings on the phenotypic plasticity of insect eggs, focusing on their developmental, microbial, defensive, and plant-environment interactions. We explore how eggs modify their physical and chemical properties to optimize survival and fitness in varying conditions. The plasticity of egg development in response to temperature fluctuations and other abiotic factors is examined, along with the role of symbiotic microbes in enhancing egg resilience. We discuss the adaptive strategies employed by eggs to defend against predators and pathogens, including changes in coloration, shell thickness, and antimicrobial secretions. Furthermore, we analyze how insect eggs respond to plant-derived cues and adapt to different host plant environments. This comprehensive overview highlights the sophisticated mechanisms underlying egg plasticity and their ecological significance in insect survival and evolution.
